moves.1. e4: Despite a large material advantage, White has to put up with some clever stalemate threats before winning this game.
moves.1... e5 2. Nc3 Nf6: This move is less aggressive than 2.Nf3, but often leads to more violent play.
moves.3. Bc4 a6 4. Nf3: Probably not very accurate, as we shall see...
moves.4... b5: If White moves the bishop, 5...b4 leads to the win of the e4 pawn. I decided to invest a piece for two pawns and a small initiative.
moves.5... Kxf7 6. Nxe5+ Ke8 7. O-O: Trying to win the e4 pawn would be dangerous because it would open up the e-file for White.
moves.7... Nc6 8. Nxc6: Keeping a small lead in development. This is important because White is slightly down in material.
moves.8... dxc6 9. e5 Ng4: Nd5 would have been much better. The knight is safe there, and Black would have an advantage.
moves.10. h3 Nxe5: Nh6 had to come into consideration, as horrible as Black's position would have been after d4.
moves.12... Bd6: Black's king isn't getting any safer. He probably should have castled. Now White will win another piece.
moves.17... Be6: Black correctly gets his other rook out, although this bishop isn't very safe on e6.
moves.19... Bc4 20. b3 Bd5 21. Nxd5 cxd5 22. R: The trick is to figure out the quickest win. Even in situations where one has an extreme material advantage, games don't win themselves.
moves.25... Kg6 26. f3 Rhf8 27. Rd6+ Rf6 28. R: White still needs to keep an eye on his back rank.
moves.32... a4 33. bxa4 b4: Black finds a way to get counterplay in a desperate situation.
moves.34. axb4 cxb4 35. Rb6 Rc4 36. a5: This pawn isn't as easy to advance as it seems.
White needs to watch out for cheap stalemate ideas like 40...g4 41.hxg4 Kg5 42.Rc6?? Ra1  43. Kh1 Rh1 !! 44.Kxh1 stalemate
moves.40... Ra5 41. Kh2 g4 42. hxg4+ Kg5: Black finds another clever way to attempt stalemate.
moves.43. Kh3 Rxa6: If White takes the rook, it's stalemate. There's no reason to be tempted by that, though, because there's a mate on the board.

gameName: VVV KINGKNOT'S KROWNED KINGKNOTHING III VVV
